Introduction

The Central Alert System (CAS) is a digital cascade system developed by the Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) and is a key means by which to communicate and disseminate important safety and device alerts within the NHS.
The system is the principle means by which organisations such as NHS England and Improvement (NHSE&I) and DHSC circulate important safety and device alerts to NHS organisations.

The Trust is expected to acknowledge receipt of each alert and complete a feedback form within the designated time to the Department of Health identifying what has been done in response to the alert. The responses are monitored externally and are available for public scrutiny via the national CAS web page.

This policy is designed to ensure a consistent approach for dealing with the management of alerts received through the CAS. It is important that all Trust personnel are aware of their roles and responsibilities with regard to dissemination and actions required in complying with alerts.
Alerts may originate from any of the following organisations:
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA);
NHSE&I Estates & Facilities Alerts;
DHSC Supply Distribution Alerts;
NHSE&I National Patient Safety Alerts;
Healthcare Safety Investigation Branch (HSIB);
Alerts from the CAS team.
It may also be necessary for the Trust to distribute “internal alerts”. These alerts will be used to provide rapid dissemination of information, e.g. medical device/equipment recall.

CAS is also used to send out emergency alerts, i.e. Chief Medical Officer Messaging and MHRA Drug Alerts. These do not require a response and are sent directly to senior Trust staff as opposed to the CAS Liaison Officer.

It is the aim of the Trust to ensure that all alerts are communicated promptly to all relevant members of staff employed within the Trust and that action to comply with alerts is taken within the Department of Health timescales in order to safeguard patients, visitors, and staff from harm.
Scope
This policy has been developed to ensure that there are robust arrangements in place for the co-ordination and management of CAS Alerts
This policy applies to all safety alerts received by the Trust via CAS. This policy does not extend to:
Security Management Service (SMS) Alerts;
National Health Service Resolution (NHSR) Alerts;
Health & Safety Executive (HSE) Alerts;
Medication Supply Disruption Alerts (SDA) which are co-ordinated by the pharmacy directorate via the Medication Safety Officer (MSO).
Definitions

table_items.text: Central Alerting System (CAS) is web-based system for distributing Patient Safety Alerts and other safety related alerts and messages to NHS Trusts and other healthcare organisations. It is accessible to all for purposes of viewing an alert via the CAS website.

Alerts are disseminated to a CAS Liaison Officer in NHS Trusts and other healthcare organisations through CAS. The CAS Liaison Officer ensures onward distribution of the alerts to the relevant Alert Leads, manages the CAS system and records action taken.
Takes responsibility for managing individual alerts within the Trust, managing an alert Action Plan and co- ordinating responses within the timescales specified in the alerts.
A ‘Field Safety Notice' (FSN) is an important communication about the safety of a medical device that is sent to customers by a device manufacturer, or their representative.

The Medical Device Safety Officer (MDSO) is responsible for the management of device-related safety alerts and supports medical device incident reporting. They will also be the main contact for NHS England, the MHRA and manufacturers.

NHS Trusts and other healthcare organisations have a designated Medication Safety Officer (MSO). This is the Principal Pharmacist for Medication Safety, supporting medication incident reporting, quality improvement and is the main contact for NHS England & Improvement.
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)

The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is a regulatory agency of the Department of Health & Social Care (DHSC) focusing on promoting public health and patient safety by ensuring that medicines, healthcare products and medical equipment meet defined standards of quality and safety.
The Patient Safety & Quality Group (PS&Q) meet on a monthly basis to ensure oversight of the patient safety agenda. As part of this, the
group will also oversee the progress of National Patient Safety Alerts.

NHS Trusts are required to identify one or more Patient Safety Specialists to provide oversight and influence in all patient safety processes within the organisation. This includes supporting compliance with National Patient Safety Alerts.

The Risk Assurance Framework (RAF) is a part of the Trust's risk management system and provides a mechanism for recording details of each risk within a database so that risk records can be analysed and facilitate effective oversight of risk management at all levels.
The Risk & Compliance Group (R&C) meet on a monthly basis to ensure there is appropriate oversight of the CAS process.
The Risk & Compliance Team maintain a system to keep a record of all details relating to an alert. This includes all correspondence and the associated action plans.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Risk & Compliance Group is responsible for:
Approval of this policy;
Overseeing and monitoring the CAS process and escalating key issues or risks to the Governance Oversight Committee;
Overseeing and reviewing the overall response to safety alerts.
Safety Alerts Assurance Group - The purpose of the Safety Alerts Assurance Group (SAAG) is to

provide assurance to the Risk and Compliance Group on behalf of the Quality Governance Committee in relation to compliance with national safety alerts published through the Central Alerting System (CAS).
monitor the implementation of actions required in response to published safety alerts and ensuring that actions are embedded into practice.
Operate as a gatekeeper for the escalation of issues or risks to the Risk and Compliance Group in relation to non-compliance with safety alerts.
Medical Devices Group is responsible for:
The scrutiny and monitoring of all equipment management processes including this policy;
Reporting to Health and Safety Group annually.
Medication Assurance Group (MAG) is responsible for:
The scrutiny and monitoring of all medicines usage and optimisation processes including medication-related aspects of this policy;
Reporting by exception into Patient Safety & Quality Group and Risk & Compliance Group quarterly.
Patient Safety and Quality Group (PS&Q) is responsible for:
Overseeing and reviewing the distribution and response to National Patient Safety Alerts.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is responsible for overall responsibility for patient safety. Operational management is delegated to the Chief Nursing Officer.
Chief Nursing Officer (CNO) is responsible for ensuring that Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust) has the necessary systems in place to enable the effective management of CAS Alerts.
Associate Director of Risk & Compliance is responsible for:
Management of the CAS Alerts process and management of the Risk and Compliance Team;
Ensuring that there is a nominated CAS Liaison Officer in place to support the Trust in the management of CAS Alerts.
Head of Risk & Compliance is responsible for:
The day-to-day management of central alerts;
Formulating and reviewing policy guidance for the alert process
Providing support and guidance to Divisions regarding alerts with the Risk & Compliance Team.
Risk and Compliance Manager is responsible for:
Acting at the Trust's CAS Liaison Officer to ensure the practical application of the alerts process;
Receiving alerts via CAS on behalf of the Trust;
Liaise with MEMS, Estates and Facilities, Pharmacy, Patient Safety and Procurement teams to ascertain the relevance of received alerts
Maintain a central record of alerts;
Distributing alerts to the designated personnel within the Divisions;
Maintain records confirming dissemination and completion of actions within timescales;
Maintaining the web-based CAS system, including acknowledging alerts,
updating the system when further information is available and the closure of alerts when completed;
Produces a monthly report on alert status to the Risk and Compliance Group and on National Patient Safety Alerts to the Patient Safety and Quality Group.
Nominated Trust Leads and Designated Alert Officers are responsible for:
Assessing whether an alert is relevant to the Trust, disseminating further within their areas of responsibility as appropriate;
Ensuring that alerts relevant for their areas are managed appropriately and to given timescales;
Ensuring an action plan is developed for the management of the alert (refer to Appendix 2);
Ensuring the Risk and Compliance Team is updated on the current progress of an alert, including any delays to meeting the alert deadline;
Where an alert cannot be completed within the deadline or implemented, ensuring a risk assessment is carried out and included on the appropriate risk
register.

Clinical Directors and Divisional Triumvirates are responsible for ensuring that there is a robust system for sharing and recording alerts received where there is action required and that all of the actions detailed in any relevant CAS alerts are implemented, managed and monitored within the required timeframes.
Ward Managers/Service Managers/Heads of Department are responsible for:
Ensuring that all staff members adhere to this policy;

Line managers are responsible for ensuring all medical equipment is purchased and maintained in accordance with this policy working with Procurement to complete the process. This includes completion of the Authority to Invest (ATI) form. They are also responsible for ensuring any significant risks associated with medical equipment, informs the local Risk Assurance Framework (RAF).
Medical Devices Safety Officer (MDSO) is responsible for:

Supporting local medical device incident reporting and learning, act as the main contact for NHSE&I, the MHRA and medical device manufacturers. The MDSO should also be a member of the National Medical Devices Safety Network;
Providing support and guidance to Divisions regarding alerts, medical device adverse incident reporting and any other related issues;
Attend the Medical Devices Group and provide feedback on related alerts
Notifying the MHRA of any changes in the MDSO.
Medication Safety Officer (MSO) is responsible for:
Supporting local medication incident reporting and learning, act as the main contact for NHSE&I and the MHRA;
The MSO is a member of the National Medication Safety Officer Network;
Providing support and guidance to divisions regarding alerts, medication adverse incident reporting and any other related issues;
Supporting the completion of actions in relation to medication use alerts;
Ensuring actions are taken in relation to medication Supply Disruption Alerts (SDA).

Procurement Department is responsible for supplying details of equipment and / or consumables procured by the Trust when detailed in an alert. Details will include when the equipment and / or consumables were last purchased, which area uses the equipment and / or consumables and the amount that is available.
All staff using / operating medical equipment will be responsible for:
Ensuring they are suitably trained to use the equipment in accordance with the appropriate policies, competencies and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).
Ensuring that, where medical equipment is found to be faulty, it is taken out of use, cleaned in accordance with the Trust's Decontamination Policy and reported to MEMS

Adverse incidents involving medical equipment should be reported using the Trust's Incident Reporting System. Dependent on the circumstances, consideration should also be given to reporting the incident to the MHRA. Where doubt exists, advice should be sought from the Health and Safety Team.
All members of staff are responsible for ensuring that they are familiar with the contents of this policy
Process
The Central Alerting System is managed by the CAS Liaison Officer. This is integrated into the role of the Risk & Compliance Manager.
Upon receiving an alert, the CAS Liaison Officer will:
Acknowledge the alert within two working days on the CAS website;

Identify the type of alert received and disseminate via e-mail to the appropriate Trust Lead (refer to appendix 3). Following up on this with the Lead/divisional team if receipt of the alert is not confirmed;
Monitor for any responses or other correspondence received in relation to the alerts within the allocated deadline;
Ensure the CAS website is updated within the allocated deadline;
Keep the Trust's safety alert management system up to date with information received;
Escalate to the Head of Risk & Compliance where an alert becomes overdue, updates are not being provided or where there are any other significant concerns;
Where an alert received requires no response on the system, the alert will be recorded on the Trust's safety alert management system for information (e.g. Chief Medical Officer Messages);
5.1.2 Upon receiving an alert from the CAS Liaison Officer, the Trust Lead will:
Assess whether the alert is relevant to the Trust and where necessary, disseminate the alert and take any other necessary action within their areas of responsibility;
Respond to the CAS Liaison Officer, indicating the relevance of the alert and confirm actions required within five working days;
Appoint a Designated Alert Officer to lead on the implementation of a relevant alert;
Ensure the CAS Alert is actioned promptly and that the Risk and Compliance Team is informed.

Ensure that where a National Patient Safety Alert has been issued, details are be included in the monthly Patient Safety and Quality report to the Quality Governance Committee to ensure the Board are notified.
5.1.3 Upon receiving an alert from the Trust Lead, the Designated Alert Lead will:
Create an action plan to address all elements of the alert and share this with the Risk and Compliance Team, providing updates as appropriate;
Complete the action plan with evidence of compliance and sustainability, returning this to the Risk and Compliance Team before the deadline;
Confirm to the Risk and Compliance Team that the alert can be closed on the CAS website as fully completed and compliant;
Conduct a risk assessment and add a risk to the appropriate RAF if the deadline cannot be met or the alert cannot be implemented.

A Field Safety Notice (FSN) is a communication from a manufacturer relating to the safety of a medical device. This will detail any safety concerns, including action to be taken that will mitigate any risks. Where an FSN is received by a divisional representative, the notice should be acknowledged and action taken as appropriate.
If an FSN is received into the Risk and Compliance Team, this should be recorded on the Trust's safety alert management system and disseminated to the appropriate team for review and action.

All CAS Alerts have an allocated deadline within which any actions required must be completed. The Trust will keep the CAS website up to date with the current progress to monitor the implementation of actions within the prescribed time limit.
Reporting adverse incidents and equipment failure

Refer to the Trust's Risk Management Policy, Incident Management Policy and Medical Equipment Policy. Where an issue arises with medical equipment that results in a near miss or patient safety incident, this should be reported on the Trust's Risk and Incident Management System.

If appropriate, an incident may need to be shared with an external organisation or a specific piece of equipment may need to be reported to MHRA. This should be done by the department identifying the fault in co-ordination with the MEMS.
The findings and learning from any incidents or reports will be shared with MEMS and the appropriate Trust staff.
Review, monitoring and escalation
This policy will be reviewed every three years or following identification that changes are required in relation to the management of CAS Alerts.

The CAS Liaison Officer will ensure that any relevant alerts are monitored to ensure they are completed within the allocated deadline. When an alert is not going to be completed on time, or is overdue without assurance of progression, they will discuss this with the Trust Lead and Designated Alert Officer. Where applicable, the Trust Lead and Designated Alert Officer should ensure a risk is added to the appropriate risk register

The CAS Liaison Officer will produce a monthly report to the Safety Alerts Assurance Group outlining the current status of open CAS Alerts. The group will seek assurance that the alerts have been allocated appropriately, that action plans to address the recommendations are in place and that they have been implemented. Compliance with CAS alerts will be escalated to the Risk and Compliance Group through the monthly risk dashboard report.
7.3.1  National Patient Safety Alerts
The current position of National Patient Safety Alerts will also be reviewed by the Patient Safety and Quality Group.

Where the Designated Alert Lead and the Trust Lead propose that actions have been completed to comply with a National Patient Safety Alert, the associated action plan must be submitted to the Patient Safety and Quality Group for assurance the requirements are met. This will also ensure executive oversight and authorisation to record ‘action completed' on the CAS portal.

Non-compliance with National Patient Safety Alerts will be monitored at the Patient Safety and Quality and reported to the Quality Governance Committee and the Board within the Integrated Quality and Performance Board report.

The  CAS  Liaison  Officer  will  escalate  to  the  Associate  Director  of  Risk  and Compliance where alerts are not completed within the timeframe, where an initial action plan is not received or at any point where there are concerns regarding the progress of an alert.
Training requirements
Managers should ensure that appropriate staff are aware of their responsibilities regarding the management of safety alerts, ensuring appropriate training and support as required.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Monitoring the status of alerts received and ensuring compliance with all issued alerts
The status of National Patient Safety Alerts
Exception reports within Integrated Quality and Performance Board report
